data.text: A Small Backpack when Cycling: What Do You Think about It?
How many people are using a small backpack while riding?
For me the absolute worst place to hang any kind of luggage whilst cycling is on my body. Others may disagree of course
data.author: Jeremy Heath

data.text: I don‚Äôt but have been considering it
data.author: Tom Monaghan

data.text: Day riding or touring? For touring, I have one with me, as a grab bag for all the valuables I don't want to keep on the bike if I pop out to a shop or something. But I strap it on top of the panniers - I have the luxury of space, so why not. On long (100+ miles) day rides, I do carry a Camelback - there's often too much stuff like water and (ironically) waterproofs, food for the whole day, layers etc., to put elsewhere. But it's a necessity - the same as Jeremy, I dislike stuff upon my body. For one thing, I've found that even the best of backpacks alter the curvature of my back, and I'm getting a lower back pain, even if there's not much weight in there. But I knew someone who toured with a 70ltr backpack without much trouble.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text:
I use a Montane Featherlite waist pack https://ultralightoutdoorgear.co.uk/featherlite-6-litre-waist-pack/
Featherlite 6 Litre Waist Pack
ultralightoutdoorgear.co.uk
data.author: Jase Hoad

data.text: No panniers can't beat emüòç
data.author: Martin Hendy

data.text: Depends what bike I am on and what I am wearing
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: I take one on tours for day trips, and visits to supermarket cost 3 euros from Decathlon.
data.author: Martin Clarke

data.text: I only carry water on my back on long rides. I have one of the packed down decathlon bags for food resupplies on multi day trips. I try not to overload my shoulders and arms.
data.author: Garrick McMullin

data.text: After just completing a 7 day off road tour of the highlands myself and my friend who rode with me are both going to try lightweight running vests, probably around 10-15L, to try and get some light bits that we always need quick access to (waterproofs, snacks, water filter, electrolytes, phones, tools etc) to try and reduce the number of bags needed on the bike to help the bikes handle better over rough terrain. Fork cages made my bike really unstable even when packed with even weight distribution, and having done some research the aero penalty is huge. Aero isn‚Äôt the first thing you think of when bikepacking, but it‚Äôs all wasted energy, which over 600km add‚Äôs up, and I‚Äôm all for making it easier!
data.author: Morgan Jones

data.text: thanks for the input, i've got fork mounts and was thinking of getting the racks but worried about the handling. Aero is a good point too.
data.author: Robert Brown

data.text: I will basically do anything I can to avoid using them again‚Ä¶ if I do, it will be with much smaller bags than the 5L ones I had.
data.author: Morgan Jones

data.text: On commutes, sure. On tours, nope. your legs will be pushing the total weight of you and your gear either way. Why put stress on you back, neck and ass if you don't have to?
data.author: Ivan Perak

data.text: For winter and on rough terrain, I like a backpack. I find it's the best place for a camera and also put a water bladder in it. In hot weather I still use a hydration vest but wouldn't want to take extra weight
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: No back pack for me! I hate having something on my back on long days in the saddle
data.author: Wayne Coombs

data.text: Hate cycling with a backpack
data.author: Jake May

data.text: Yes almost always. On short trips day rides I take a Camelback Mule. For anything longer increase the back size and or use a frame bag.
data.author: Dale Weatherson

data.text: Not a Chance, that's what panniers n racks are for... üòé
data.author: Larry Gowar

data.text: I use one for water and some food and my sleeping bag on longer trips in hot places where water supply is very limited / non existent. On the trip this pic was took on I was ‚Äúaway from water‚Äù for 3 days ‚Ä¶ so it was a heavy bag at the start but soon lightened up üòä
data.author: Adi Smith

data.text: My back is not designed to be a shock absorber. It is having trouble enough coping with the insults meeted out by our potholed roads, without adding to its load.
data.author: Henk Bakker

data.text: After riding with one for years, I ended up with some severe lower back damage and neck problems after ignoring the aches and pains. I now ride with paniers and riding is a pleasure again. Short-term, I'd say go for it. But for any decent milage, put the weight elsewhere and let your legs deal with it instead.
data.author: Dee Ball

data.text: Keep one in my pannier for anytime I leave the bike (cafe, loo, shop etc).
data.author: Mike Bell

data.text: Absolutely not! Sweaty, uncomfortable etc. I have enough carrying capacity on the bike that I don't need (& don't want) a backpack as well, thank you!
data.author: Mark James
